text:
<@UC2A2ARPT>, yeah, I guess it's next to impossible to keep up with everyone's projects here, so thanks for engaging with mine, but no pressure :)

I hear you, I've also had the experience of being exited by new features in code editors, then trying them properly and getting somewhat disappointed. One relevant example is the minimap scrollbar which I believe was invented, or at least popularized, by Sublime Text. There's nothing _wrong_ with the idea or implementation, a minimap is just not as game-changing to my workflow as I originally hoped, because the shape of my code is not _that_ recognizable when zoomed out far. I was gonna talk about this in video #2 but cut it to keep the length down and the focus sharp.

Hmm, I wonder if some ideas are easier to evaluate at a glance, while others are harder and require an almost finished implementation. So choosing to develop one of the hard-to-evaluate ideas is a bigger gamble. One might spend years, only to discover that it was a bad idea. And I believe that the implementation of #2 would be particularly challenging. I'd probably need to consult with someone way better at math than me. In case anyone's curious, the challenge is to decide the font size for each row. Well, the initial "overview from outside in" view is trivial, the font size is simply a function of the tree depth, but the "context from inside out" views are much trickier. I came up with a system of constraints (font size of row A is <= row B, when caret is at row C) but for <https://emilprogviz.com/stretchy-code-map/toggle.html|the prototype> I precalculated a solution offline, and also tweaked sizes by hand, which obviously won't work in a real editor.

text: Just now I suddenly understood another smart move of yours: the focus on public domain publishing. Because commercial publishers on the web like to collect detailed statistics on which articles get the most views etc, and that's impossible in your layout (without eye tracking). Public domain publishers, on average, probably care less about optimizing for clicks. Again, I might be stating the obvious, but smart move!

text:
Garth, thanks for the warm words! And I agree about the similarities. Although I and westoncb tried to solve different problems, the resulting "look & feel" is similar when our lines shift up and down with smooth animation. You <@USJ899UUD> seem to value high framerates and distinct visual & auditory feedback - did you also work on games, by any chance? I find that level of polish to be common in games but depressingly rare in most other software.

Dammit, now I can't help but fantasize about how to combine your TiledText editing with my varying font sizes... You're right that simply shrinking the font size as a function of tree depth wouldn't be good enough, because no one wants to select, cut&paste text that's 3px high. That's why the active line in <https://emilprogviz.com/stretchy-code-map/toggle.html|my prototype> is always at full size. In TiledText you probably want all lines that you're cycling through to be at full size? But other lines, that are not in the current cycle, could vary? So when functions are collapsed, for example like on the 1st frame of <https://youtu.be/tztmgCcZaM4|your demo video>, maybe instead of being completely collapsed to 1 line, the function bodies could be displayed with the tree-depth-scaling method, quite small, as "thumbnails" or "previews" of what you'll see when you expand them. There's a part in the video where you say "let me go to a longer method real quick" and open the right one by memory, but with "thumbnails" you wouldn't need to remember. There's ofc a trade-off between making the cycle-list maximally compact, and making the "thumbnails" readable, but that's a knob one can turn to find a sweet spot.

Hmm, there's some more overlap coming in my next video, number #5. I wonder if there a term for when we're trying to solve different problems, and still end up with similar solutions. Not exactly "convergent evolution", but close.

Sidetrack: I've always wanted a good visualizer of data structures, and I had started to sketch out the basics when I saw westoncb's work <http://symbolflux.com/projects/avd|Lucidity> a few years back, which made me promptly drop my own project because you seem to be already creating exactly the kind of visualization I wanted. Thanks for that overlap! Very impressive work, I hope you'll release it some day!
